titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Morning call at Mr Edward Cruft’s: his wife is at Newbury-Port— Met William Tudor at the Athenaeum and he accompanied me to see the Panorama of Athens. I asked him to call upon me next Monday at Noon, and told him I would then shew him a Letter from the President of the United States concerning him and a Commission for him as Commercial Agent at Lima, if it suited him to accept it— I went to W. P. Greenwood’s, and had a tooth, which has been sometime troublesome, drawn—Greenwood was an acquaintance of mine at Newbury-Port in 1789. and I have scarcely seen him since. Dined with my wife, and a party, at Joseph Hall’s the Sheriff’s.— President Kirkland was there— Charles was yesterday admitted at the University on condition of passing a satisfactory examination in Sallust, after the vacation— Mr. Quincy called at 5 O’Clock for me at Hall’s and I came out in his Chaise with him to my father’s— I found W. S. Shaw here; and my wife, with all my family.

2. VI: This day, like the latter part of yesterday was rainy— I heard Mr Whitney, in the morning from Matthew 6.34. “Take therefore no thought for the morrow; for the morrow shall take thought for the things of itself. Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof”—a text upon which Mr Francis had preached last Sunday; and in the afternoon from 2. Corinthians 7.2. “Receive us; we have wronged no man, we have corrupted no man, we have defrauded no man.” General Miller, the Governor of the Arkansas territory was here this Evening with his daughter, who has been some-time residing at Mrs Black’s— I examined my Son Charles this day in several passages, and among the rest in that upon which he had been examined on Friday— I found him ready enough at parsing and sufficiently familiar with the grammatical construction of the sentences. But his deficiency consists in comprehending the precise meaning of many words in the sense annexed to them in any particular sentence— He applies to a word in one passage a meaning which it might have in another, but which it has not in that— This mistake in the meaning of a significant word, makes him miss that of the whole sentence to which it belongs— It shews that he is not yet well grounded in the Latin language; yet his construction of the passage in which he was examined was so nearly right that I could not avoid the suspicion that he had been unfairly treated— His examiner was Mr. Channing, the professor of Rhetoric and Oratory, a man himself quite incompetent to the Office, which he holds; palmed upon the University against the general voice of the public; and all but a majority of the Overseers—Hated and despised by the Students— Having never yet delivered a public Lecture, though he has been nearly two years in Office; and so ignorant, or so careless of the very elements of Oratory, that he has never given a tittle of instruction to any of his pupils to teach them even to speak loud enough to be heard— Why he should have been the examiner in Sallust, I know not.

3. VI— There was some heavy thunder in the Night— Mr G. A. Otis visited my father this Morning. Also Mr Shaler, and Dr Eustis who engaged us to dine with him next Thursday. I came into Boston with my wife and Mary Hellen— William Tudor called upon me at noon. I shewed him the Letter from the President, proposing that he should be appointed commercial agent at Lima, and put into his hands the Commission which I received on Saturday from the Department of State— He told me as I had expected that he could not accept it, a commercial establishment not being particularly suited to his views, and if it were the condition of Lima being so uncertain that his only prospect would be of a very precarious contingency— I gave him nevertheless the papers, requesting him to look over them, and if he should definitively decline the Commission to return them to me— Just as I was going out to dinner Mr William King of Maine, one of the Commissioners of claims under the Florida Treaty called on me— He is passing through this Town on his way to Washington where the Meeting of the Commissioners is adjourned to the 10th. of this Month— I dined at Mr Samuel Cobb’s with the trustees of the humane Society—Governor Brooks and Lieutenant Governor Phillips were there. A French man by the name of Guillé went up from the Common in a Balloon; we saw him in the air from Mr Cobb’s garden, and it somewhat discomposed the dinner— I returned to Mrs Jenks’s before dark, and did not again go out— For a violent tempest which had been lowering the whole day came on in great fury with rain and a warm South-east
wind, which continued all the Evening and into the Night. Mr Guille was not more than a quarter of an hour upon his aerial voyage, and came down in Malden. There were a number of visitors who called on me this day, and among them Mr B. Gorham, the member of Congress and Mr. Samuel Gardner.

4. VI:Mr Shaler called upon me this morning with Mr Folsom, whom he introduced. This is a meritorious young man, whom I should rejoice to serve, but have not, nor see any prospect of having the power. I called at the Branch Bank of the United States, and at Noon heard the Address delivered by Judge Story to the Members of the Suffolk bar— It was a learned historical review of the Science of the law, which gave general satisfaction; though I thought there was rather too much of panegyric upon English judges, especially Lord Mansfield and Sir William Scott. Some qualification should have tempered his admiration of judges who have mingled too much of the politician with their judicial characters. I think he also underrated the learning and talents of our own lawyers, who lived before the Revolution. He paid a very handsome tribute to the memory of his pupil Gallison who had also been mine; and who died last winter in the prime of life. In speaking of his decease the judge was overpowered by his sensibility, burst into tears and was obliged to set down for several minutes before he could proceed— I dined, by invitation with this Society of the Suffolk bar at Concert Hall. General William Sullivan presided, and there were from ninety to a hundred persons present, of whom fifteen or twenty might be invited guests— The after dinner was convivial with songs and humorous technical toasts— I left them about Sunset, and spent the Evening with my wife and Mary Hellen, at Mr Richard Derby’s, where there was a Ball— They sat me down to a game of Chess with young Crommelin, which I lost— We came home about 11. O’Clock, much fatigued. Dr Townsend called upon me to day, and asked me to visit to-morrow the marine hospital at Charlestown of which he is the Superintendent— I had already promised Dr Parkman to visit the Hospital recently built by a subscription in this town— I have engaged also to go to Salem the week after next, and to dine with Mr Silsbee the 19th. and with judge Story the 20th. of this Month— The Storm of last Night continued with great violence till two or three O’Clock this Morning. It roused us several times in the Night.

5. VI.Dr Parkman called upon me this Morning at 11. and I visited with him the newly erected hospital at West-Boston, and the Marine Hospital at Charlestown— The former is a very costly stone building, not yet completed: built by subscription, but in a style so expensive that it has absorbed all the funds subscribed, and left nothing to defray the current charges for maintaining the establishment. They propose therefore to receive patients not gratuitously, but at a board of 3 dollars a week, and have a project of engaging at that price the Seamen who are now received at the Marine Hospital in Charlestown. This I also visited with Dr Parkman, and found there General Dearborn the younger, Collector at Boston, Dr Townsend and his Son— The Marine Hospital is kept in very good order, and the patients are as comfortable as their circumstances permit— I went through the bed chambers and saw them all— Some complaint has been made at the Navy Department of the expensiveness of this hospital, and it was intimated to me, that the principal motive for this complaint was that the building was wanted for the purposes of the Navy-Yard.— It was observed also that the expences were less than the three dollars a week for each patient, which would be required at the New Hospital, and that this building was not large enough to accommodate the number of Patients usually provided for at the Marine Hospital. I had visited the latter once before, when it was under the superintendence of Dr. Waterhouse. As we were returning through Charlestown, we stopped at the house of a Mr Jaques, a virtuoso in the breed of cattle, and saw several remarkably fine animals, particular a Bull, and an English Dray Horse, both of which he keeps for breeding. He was not
himself at home. On our return to Boston, I alighted at Dr. Parkman’s, and saw his wife, a daughter of the former British Consul M’Donough— Afterwards I went with Harriet Welsh, my son George, and John Boyd to Mr Wiggin’s, and saw his picture of the Capucin Chapel, which is much celebrated. He brought it with him from Italy. Its merit consists in a striking exhibition of perspective, by the admission of light only through one window at the end of the chapel— Dined with my wife at Mr William Gray’s in Summer Street— We went to his house at Cambridge, supposing the invitation had been to dine there. Harriet Welsh and her sister Bailey’sdaughter went with us, and stopped at Mr Keating’s— Finding Mr Gray’s house at Cambridge shut up, we returned to Boston— They were yet waiting for us in Summer Street— Among the company was Mr Ward Chipman, brother to Mrs Gray, and now the British Agent to the Commission under the 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent— President Kirkland was also there, and I spoke to him of the condition annexed to Charles’s admission at the University. I told him I had myself examined Charles in several passages of Sallust, and although I had found him not perfect in his Construction, yet I did not think his deficiency such as justified the making his admission conditional; and I plainly intimated a suspicion, that Mr Channing had not treated him fairly. I asked him by whom the examination would be after the vacation— He said by Mr Channing again, who he hoped had not suffered and would not suffer any prejudice to bias his judgment— And added that if at the end of the vacation Charles would be at Cambridge by 9 O’Clock, his examination should immediately take place. I determined to go with him myself— I spent the Evening at Sheriff Hall’s.

6. V:15.Mr Degrand called upon me, with a number of papers relating to a claim of Joseph N. Howe upon the Navy Department— It is for an allowance upon an account to indemnify him for losses sustained by him in consequence of his having been paid in depretiated Treasury Notes, during the late War— He has already had one negative answer from the Secretary of the Navy, but wishes the case to be reconsidered. Degrand told me there were several precedents, and instanced particularly the case of the State Bank in which it had been at first denied, and afterwards at my intercession allowed— I advised that Mr Howe should address a second Letter to the Secretary of the Navy, renewing the demand, and specifically stating all the stating all the cases in which he could ascertain that the allowance has been made— I said if the precedents could be shewn to be entirely parallel in principle, I thought the Secretary of the Navy would make the allowance to Mr Howe; but if he should not, Howe should petition Congress, and get Dr. Eustis or Mr Gorham to present his petition, which would of course be referred to the Committee of claims; and the precedents would be as useful to exhibit to them, as to the Secretary of the Navy. I called immediately after Breakfast at E. Cruft’s, but he was not at home— Meeting then with Dr Parkman, I went with him to Mr Benjamin Dearborn’s, the inventor of Patent Scales, and of many other ingenious contrivances— He is a man of considerable inventive faculties, and is now a maker of brass weights. I examined some of his scales, which are made upon principles differing little from those of Mr Pollock; whom he charges with having borrowed without his leave from him— Mr Dearborn’s other inventions are chiefly of small household conveniences, such as fastenings of windows, springs for shutting gates and economical self extinguishing lamps— He had some Chinese brass weights which he asked me to accept, and I bespoke of him, a brass avoirdupois pound of his own making— After leaving him I called again at Mr Crufts without finding him at home, but soon afterwards met him— I went with him to his Store, on one of the wharves, and opened several of the boxes, and trunks of my books which are in his custody— They have remained packed up ever since they arrived from England, whence I sent them on my return to this Country in 1817. I found them in good order, and undamaged, though with a number of moths among the papers— Met on the wharf Lieutenant Rose, who under Captain Bainbridge commanded the Columbus upon her late Cruize in the Mediterranean— I went out with my wife and Mary Hellen, and dined with Dr Eustis at Roxbury. My brother and my Son George were there from Quincy. Mr and Mrs Morton, were of the company; and Mrs Morton was seized suddenly with violent illness while at dinner.
She partly recovered so as to return to the table, but was finally compelled early after dinner to retire. We returned to Boston, and I visited Dr Jarvis at Mr Burr’s. Saw Mr Burr also. Spent the Evening with my wife at Mrs Gerry’s where we met a numerous company.

7. V:30. Morning at the Athenaeum. I am daily receiving Letters from D. Brent Chief Clerk of the Department of State, enclosing papers of importance received there. The circumstances of my situation here make it impossible for me properly to attend to them; but I despatched this day a second Letter to Mr Brent, with a draft of a reply to a Letter from the Spanish Minister General Vivés. Mr John Dodge a Merchant who has resided several years in the Island of St Domingo on Hayti, came and delivered to me a long memorial, urging the expediency of an immediate formal acknowledgment of the mulatto Government there. He also endeavoured to impress upon me the importance of this measure in conversation— But there are objections to it, which he did not take into his calculation— I promised to forward his memorial to the President. Dined with my wife at Mr Samuel Parkman’s, with a company of about 25 persons, principally of his family which is very numerous. Mr and Mrs Gray were there; and Mr Chipman. My wife spent the Evening at Mr W. C. Gray’s, with a large party; but I had been since last week engaged to Degrand, where I met also a numerous company of republicans. Artiguenave was there, and as I was returning home, overtook and walked with me. His main object was to tell me that H. G. Otis was the instigator of all the clamour in this town against my fourth of July address, and he expressed his astonishment at the excessive partiality prevailing among many people here for England. He said that he himself had been so much pleased with the Address, that he had made a translation of it into French, and sent it to Marshal Grouchy, now in France— He also told me that Joseph Bonaparte, who lives at Bordentown in New-Jersey, and goes by the name of the Count de Survilliers, had received advices from St. Helena, relating to the death of his brother Napoleon. That they were very disgraceful to the British Government, and that Joseph had been inclined to publish them in the Newspapers here, but he Artiguenave had written to him to dissuade him from it— I had left Degrand’s early intending to go to W. C. Gray’s; but Artiguenave detained me until my wife came home, and it was then too late.

8. VI: I received a Letter from Mr Edward Everett, editor of the North-American Review, requesting me to furnish for that work, a review of Don Luis de Onis’s Memoir upon the Negotiation of the Florida Treaty. This I have not time to do now, but may perhaps undertake it after my return to Washington. Harriet Welsh and Miss Hinckley called upon Mrs Adams and we visited Mr Hinckley’s new house, which is not quite finished; but is fitting up in a Style both of magnificence and of comfort, and which is to be warmed by fires in the cellar with great economy of fuel— This recent invention has been introduced into many of the new houses in Boston. My wife finds herself so unwell in consequence of the life we are leading, racing about twice a day at dinners and Balls, in town and Country, receiving multitudes of visits and expected to return them all, that she concluded to break off from it entirely, and this morning went with Mary Hellen out to my fathers at Quincy, determined not to come to Boston again during our present Northern visit; at least not to accept invitations to parties. I had visits from General Brown, with Mr J. T. Austin, and from Mr J. Appleton of Cambridge, and paid visits to Mr Jonathan Mason, Callender and John Phillips, neither of whom was at home. At the Athenaeum I met Captain Partridge, who keeps a Military Academy of Cadets in Vermont. His school is now in vacation, and he is here with ten or twelve of his pupils— He gave me a printed prospectus of his terms, and asked me whether I thought he could visit my father with his boys, who were desirous of seeing him— The West-Point Cadets who were here about a Month since went out and breakfasted at his house, and he made them a short Address, which has been very much admired. Partridge’s is a
mere private school, but in which his desire is to rivalize with the Academy of West-Point— I dined at George Blake’s with a company of more than 20. among whom were Generals Brown, Scott, and Boyd and Coll. Towson— After dinner, I came out with Shaw to my father’s house at Quincy. As we were leaving Mrs Jenks’s house, William Tudor who had dined with us at Blake’s called, and gave me a volume of Miscellanies which he has this day published. My Son Charles went this day to Boston, and returned to Quincy this Evening in the Stage.

9. VI. Bathed this morning with my Sons George and John, in the Creek behind Mrs Black’s— Heard Mr. Colman, now of Brookline; in the Morning from Luke 18.18. “And a certain ruler asked him, saying, Good Master, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?” and in the afternoon from Proverbs 2.11. “Discretion shall preserve thee, understanding shall keep thee.” They were both excellent discourses, and as a writer of Moral Dissertations, none of the Clergymen of this neighbourhood surpass Colman— His text of this afternoon struck me particularly, both as admonition and consolation. I invited him to dine with us; my father being somewhat unwell, and not having attended Meeting. He asked us to call at his house at Brookline, on our way to Princeton, and to dine with him upon our return. I promised him to call either in going or returning— There came as visitors to my father this day, Generals Brown and Scott, and Lieutenants Kirby and Monroe; but I did not see them— Degrand came, and I strolled with him over the hills— Binon was with him— The Evening visitors were Mr Quincy and his Son, Captain Beale, and Mr Marston.

10. VI:My father concluded to go with us to Princeton, and this morning at nine we left his house. He went with my wife and my Son George in our Carriage, and I in his Chaise, and a horse with John— We left Charles to follow us to-morrow in the Stage to Worcester. We stopped at Mr Colman’s house at Brookline and found his and his wife’s mother there— He and Mrs Colman had not returned from Hingham, where they have been upon a visit, and whence Mr Colman came yesterday to Quincy. After a repose of an hour for my father we proceeded on the Worcester turnpike eight Miles to Sibley’s Hotel at Needham where we dined; and then 7 1/4 Miles to Hamilton’s at Framingham where we stop for the Night. My wife finding the Chaise an easier vehicle of conveyance than our carriage, I exchanged Seats with her at Needham, and she came on with John. At Framingham we met Dr Baldwin a Clergyman of Boston— Mr Maynard, heretofore a member of the Senate of Massachusetts from the County of Middlesex, and with whom I sat the only year that I was a member of that body. And George found here his Classmate Cheney with whom he went and passed the Night— This house of Hamilton’s is an excellent inn; and that of Sibley at Needham is a very good one. But the Turnpike road like most of the others in the Commonwealth, having yet very few dwelling houses built upon them, exhibit a dreary and barren Country. Pastures, Indian corn and potatoe fields, and apple orchards constitute the chief cultivation; interspersed with Oak, walnut, Chesnut and Pine woodlands. This is the general face of Massachusetts, but nothing presents it to so great disadvantage as the Turnpike roads— Shaw returned this morning from Quincy to Boston, and My niece Mrs Clarke, with her child Susan, left it, to go and pass the winter at Georgetown.

11. V:30. Immediately after I rose this morning, the master of the House, Hamilton took me into a back room, and told me that he was sorry to be the bearer of disagreeable intelligence; but an unfortunate accident had happened yesterday at my father’s house; and there was a Messenger, who had come express with Letters to me concerning it. I desired immediately to see him— He brought me two Letters from Mr Quincy. One written with the intention of sending it by my Son Charles, and the other later, when he had concluded to send on his Man, as an Express— They were to inform me that about noon yesterday, the roof of my father’s house was discovered to be on fire; and as it blew at the time a brisk gale, the saving of the house had for some-time been despaired of. That by dint of very great exertions the fire had been subdued, but that the house was uninhabitable, and great damage had been done to the furniture, and to the doors and windows of
the house in attempting to save them. Quincy advised me not to mention this event to my father, but to proceed upon our Journey, and observed that in the course of ten days the house would be entirely repaired and ready to receive my father again. But knowing the fortitude of my father’s character, I did not think it consistent with my duty to him to conceal from him an event in which his property was interested. I did not feel myself authorized to decide for him, withholding from him the state of facts, the question which naturally arose, whether he should on this emergency proceed upon his journey or return home— I therefore immediately told him what had happened. He received the intelligence with perfect composure, and after a short deliberation, determined to proceed— At 7. O’Clock after breakfasting at Hamilton’s, we rode ten miles to Wesson’s at Westborough; there rested an hour and came 9 Miles to Sikes’s tavern at Worcester.— There we found Mr Boylston, who was much surprized and delighted to see my father. He had not expected him— The Court of Sessions for the County was this day meeting, and we fell in with Dr Bancroft the clergyman, my old Classmate Dr Oliver Fiske, Mr Allen the Clerk of the Court, Mr Ward the Sheriff, and Messrs. Hastings, Lincoln and Bigelow, members of the Bar. We dined at Worcester, and after dinner, I went with Mr Boylston, and saw the building erected for the antiquarian Society. We met there Mr Isaiah Thomas, the original founder of the Society. The building is not yet finished, nor is there anything very remarkable in the antiquities which it contains— They are chiefly typographical; old books and newspapers— Mr Boylston presented to me, the Selectmen of Princeton, who to my surprize and mortification, had come all the way to Worcester, to do me honour— Boylston also told me that a cavalcade of the inhabitants of Princeton would meet us at the entrance of the town, and escort us to his house; and that they had an Address prepared to present me— That they had done all this of their own accord, without any agency or interference on his part— I told Mr Boylston, that I felt as grateful as possible to the inhabitants of Princeton for their kindness— That if I had come alone as they had expected, however conscious I should have been of having no pretension to the compliment which they were disposed to honour me with, I would not have declined it; but that being with my father, there would in my mind be so gross an incongruity in my receiving an honorary address of welcome, while he was present and unnoticed, that I relied upon him to excuse me with those Gentlemen, for declining to receive it— He said he would settle the matter with them entirely to my satisfaction. In proceeding from Worcester to Princeton, my father and my wife went with Mr Boylston in his carriage; I followed with George in mine, and John brought up the rear in the Chaise— I made this arrangement, that the cavalcade and the escort might be for my father, and I only one of his suite— The cavalcade met us about half way from Worcester, and the gentleman at the head of it, successively came and welcomed, first my father, and then myself. But he delivered to me the written Address, which they had agreed upon, and had added to it, a short Address to my father. The escort consisted of nearly one hundred horsemen; and they conducted us to Mr Boylston’s house. It was fifteen Miles from Worcester, and we arrived there after dark, somewhat annoyed with the rain— A collation had been provided for them by Mr Boylston, after which they at their desire passed in review, dismounted, before us, under the porch of Mr. Boylston’s house— Boylston told me it was by mistake that the Address had been delivered to me, and that no answer would be expected to it. I had verbally answered with suitable thanks the welcome of the Captain of the cavalcade, and desired Mr Boylston to cause all the Gentlemen who had taken part in it, and in the address, to be assured, that I felt deeply sensible of the honour they had done me, and in omitting a written answer to the Address, was governed only by the motives which I had alledged for declining it— He promised that he would. The truth was that I had no doubt that
the Address and the escort had both been gotten up, if not under his direct influence, at least in compliance with his wish, and because he had thought it would be gratifying to me. He had not expected my father, and had not considered how unbecoming it would be in me to receive an address merely of welcome, in his presence— But not being ambitious of ridicule, and holding in very low estimation thatmode of popular approbation, I was glad to avail myself of any good reason for escaping from an Address.— My father and my wife were both much fatigued at the end of our Journey, and the latter had in the evening a turn of fainting— The marshal of the cavalcade was Coll. Gill.

12. VI:30. The morning was dull and rainy. My Son John went with the Chaise to Worcester, to fetch his brother Charles, who came yesterday to that place from Boston in the Stage. Charles however came from Worcester without waiting for him and arrived here before John returned— We were confined most of the Morning by the weather, but before dinner I took an hour’s walk with George. Dr Thayer, Minister of a church at Lancaster, and Mr Clarke Minister at Princeton, with his wife, and Mr Boylston’sson John, dined with us— The afternoon and evening were fair, and we viewed the barnyard and cattle, interesting objects to farmers. The barn is 160 feet long and 60 wide—well filled with provender for a hundred head of Cattle and sheep in proportion— In the evening we had conversation.

13. VI: The day was fair and cool; and I walked with my Sons to the top of Wachusett hill, which is about 3 Miles from Mr Boylston’s house— Its top is nearly 3000 feet above the level of the Sea, and it is said to be the highest elevation in the Commonwealth— There is therefore nothing physically very lofty in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. The Monadneck, about 30 miles distant from it in New-Hampshire is two or three hundred feet higher— From the top of Wachusett its distance to the eye would seem to be less than ten Miles— The prospect from Wachusett is extensive, and the Blue Hills near Boston are distinctly seen from it. I fancied I saw through the glass a part of Boston itself— The Hill is for the most part steep of ascent and covered with wood— There is no path even to ascend for a horse, and we were conducted by a guide. A carriage road over it might however easily be made— We were an hour going up, and as long coming down, although the distance is not more than a mile and a half. The large growth of trees—Oak, Ash and pine extends perhaps two thirds of the way to the top, the rest is mere shrubbery, and the line of separation between the large and small wood goes round the hill at the same elevation, as regularly as though it were drawn with compasses. We returned to Mr Boylston’s to dinner, and afterwards walked round the farm again— The only book I have found here is a volume, published last year, by Mr Boylston’s friend John Nicholls, who was a member of Parliament during the War of the American Revolution, and several years after. I read part of it this day, and found it contained many curious and interesting anecdotes— Nicholls was an Independent member, always in opposition during the American War, and by an attachment to Charles Fox, then formed, drawn into the support of the Coalition Ministry, and their India-Bill, which he now very frankly condemns— His book, entitled “Recollections” bears hard upon the reputation and memory of Fox, of William Pitt, and especially, and much too severely of Edmund Burke, by far the greatest man of the three. Against him Nicholls indulges a strong personal animosity; and he represents him, probably with truth as the author of the India Bill which went under the name of Fox— He also attributes Burke’s prosecution of Hastings to interested and sordid motives—I hope unjustly.

14. VI.Mr Boylston has been earnestly urging us all to prolong our visit to him until next Tuesday; but having perceived that my father was uneasy at the situation of his house, and anxious to get home, I referred it this morning to him, offering if he so preferred to accompany him myself now, leaving my wife, and George to return in the Chaise next Tuesday, and John and Charles in the Stage— He concluded accordingly to depart, and we left Mr Boylston’s house this morning between nine and ten— Mr Boylston accompanied us to Lancaster, 12 Miles coming through Sterling, and my Sons John and Charles, who returned with him to Princeton— We stopped at Lancaster, to visit the Cotton factory there, which is in a flourishing State— Dined at Rand’s— Mr Boylston sent for his grandson, a boy of five or six years old who is at school at Dr Thayer’s— We also visited the new Meeting House near the tavern—and walking out after dinner,
I met without recognizing him Mr Asa Packard— He came afterwards to see us, at the tavern, and we went to his house. He was formerly settled as a Minister at Marlborough, but has parted from his parish and removed to Lancaster. His wife was Nancy Quincy, whom I remember from my earliest childhood, as the most intimate friend of my Sister— I had scarcely seen her these thirty-five years, but I now found her with two Sons and two Daughters, all men and women of full age— About 4. in the afternoon we took leave of Mr Boylston, who returned to Princeton, taking with him my Sons John and Charles, and his little Grandson, and I came with my father to Whitmore’s at Stow, 13 Miles, and here stop for the Night.— Before I left Princeton this morning, Mr Boylston told me that he had wished to have some conversation with me concerning his own affairs; but it was chiefly to say that he had in his Will appointed me one of his Executors, and made such provisions in it as he trusted I should not disapprove—but as my public engagements might prevent me from being within the State he had made such arrangements for the settlement of his Affairs, that my constant presence would not be required— He only wished to recommend his grandchild to my particular kindness, for the care of his education— I said that earnestly hoping that the time was far remote when his affairs would need the Execution of his Will, I could only assure him that at any and at all times I should be gratified in lending any aid in my power to the care and education of the child— He replied that his health was now good, but his age was 72. and he was subject to complaints which might remove him suddenly. In which case he should rely upon my friendly regard for the child, and that I should have very little trouble otherwise in the Execution of his Will.

15. VI:15. Quincy— At 7 this morning we left Stow, intending to stop on our passage through Waltham at Mr C. Gore’s; but we passed without being aware of it two miles beyond his house, and rested for an hour at Stratton’s in Watertown, 16 Miles from Stow— Thence we came on 7 Miles to Boston, and alighted just at Noon at Mr James H. Foster’s, where we dined. We found Mary Hellen there, and after dinner brought her out with us to my father’s House, where we arrived between 5 and 6 in the afternoon. While in Boston, I called at the Athenaeum, where I found five or six large packets of despatches from D. Brent at Washington. I met also in Boston, Mr J. Marston, and Mr Silsbee of Salem, who told me he had been invited by Mr Colman to dine this day with him at Brookline, and that he expected us there— Mr Shaw came out also this evening from Boston— On our return from Princeton, we travelled not on the Turnpike, but upon the old roads— The Houses of Entertainment were not so good, but the face of the Country, much more pleasant and better cultivated— The improvement in the face of the Country, and in the aspect of the dwelling houses within the last 30 years is great and cheering— It presents every where an appearance of comfort and plenty— We found the house at my fathers in a great measure repaired; the carpenters being still at work upon it— Part of the roof had been consumed; and the fire must have kindled from a spark issuing from the kitchen chimney— It is a new proof of the extreme danger of shingle roofs, which when old are no better than stubble. The house was saved by my brother’s going on the top of it and cutting away the part of the roof nearest to the fire, and by wet blankets spread over the part which was actually on fire— This was done by the advice of a Stranger, who was travelling by, while the fire was burning and whose house had been saved some months since by the same expedient. There was great damage done not only to much of the furniture, but to the windows and doors of the house in the attempt to save them by casting them out of the house. This frequently happens at fires. The first sentiment suited to this narrow escape from a great calamity, is that of thankfulness for the preservation— The second should be, of precaution for the future— A prudent man should have not only fire-buckets, bed Screws, and bags in his house, but should never be without a ladder. He should also have a few written or printed regulations, how to proceed in cases of fire, well impressed
upon his own mind and upon those of his family. He should also have his dwelling house insured. I have insurance upon all mine in Boston, but not upon those at Washington.

16. VI: My despatches are so voluminous that I have not been able to read one third of them through in the course of this day. Heard Dr Porter of Roxbury this morning from Job. 7.1. “Is there not an appointed time to man upon earth? are not his days also like the days of an hireling?”—and in the afternoon from Ezekiel 33.13. “When I shall say to the righteous that he shall surely live: if he trust to his own righteousness and commit iniquity, all his righteousness shall not be remembered; but for his iniquity that he hath committed, he shall die for it.” The morning sermon was funereal, upon the death of Captain John Hall’swife—and they were both excellent moral discourses— Dr Porter called this afternoon with his nephew at my father’s, but stopped only a few minutes, as he was then just ready for a ride with me, round through the Milton and back over the Neponset Bridge Road. We were overtaken by the rain— Captain Beale, Mr Quincy and his Son spent the Evening at my father’s.

17. VI:W. S. Shaw returned this morning to Boston, and I sent by him a packet of despatches and a Letter to D. Brent: chiefly relating to claims of Coll. Todd, the agent to Venezuela and the Colombian Republic; and I was engaged at the Office until noon in further reading the despatches I had received on Saturday. I then walked to Mr John Greenleaf’s— He resides at the antient dwelling house of my uncle Cranch, his wife’s father a house and neighbourhood which always brings to my mind numerous associations of my childhood and youth— I found Mr and Mrs Greenleaf with only two of their children at home—Mary about 14 and Richard 12 years old— Their eldest Son, John is settled at Baltimore, in partnership with a son of Judge Dawes who married his Sister Lucy— Another son, William is at Philadelphia, and another Daniel in Mr Hinckley’s Store at Boston. They have reared this large family upon very slender resources— I returned home across the hills and found my father and the family already at dinner— I received a note from Lieutt. Stockton, requesting me to appoint a time when I could see him, which I answered by fixing to-morrow at one O’Clock at Mrs Jenks’s in Boston— Took a ride again with my father this afternoon and we went to the Mount Wollaston farm— Mr Marston spent the Evening here.

18. VI: After writing two Letters to D. Brent; and making up a packet of despatches for the Department of State, I came in to Boston, in time to meet Lieutenant Stockton at one O’Clock. In cruizing on the Coast of Africa, for Slave-traders, he took four vessels under french Colours one of which was brought into Boston, the other three were retaken by their crews— The French Minister has made a formal complaint against these captures, and has demanded that the Jeune Eugénie the vessel brought in here, should be delivered up, either to the agent of the owners, or to the French Consul that she may be sent for trial to France— The President strongly inclines to the delivery, and as the report of Lieutt. Stockton to the Navy Department concerning the transaction was scanty, the Secretary of the Navy has instructed him to report more particularly to me— When I first arrived here Lieutt. Stockton was absent, and only returned at the close of the last week— He enquired with regard to what particulars, I should wish his report, and I told him; that it must be special stating his motives for the capture in each case separately and that he should state every circumstance tending to prove, first that the vessels captured were actually engaged in the slavetrade, and secondly, that American Citizens were interested in the property of them. This he promised to do, and said that the proof on the first point would leave no doubt of the fact, and on the second would amount at least to a violent presumption— I told him of the President’s desire that the vessel now here should be delivered up to the French Consul, and of the advice I had given that a Court of enquiry should be called to report upon his conduct in making the captures, which I assured him, was altogether in good-will to him, being persuaded that the report of the Court would be in his favour, and would also enable me to give a satisfactory answer to the complaint of the French Minister— The Lieutenant did not incline to a Court of enquiry, apprehending that it might be assigned to officers, not sufficiently versed in the Laws applicable to his proceedings— He said however
that if the Government should think a Court of Enquiry necessary he should not object to it. I dined at Mrs Jenks’s, and after dinner called at the Athenaeum; while I was there Mr Stewart the Painter came in, enquiring for Shaw. His object was to fix on a day for going out to my father’s. Stewart is painting a portrait of him; and after copying that which he formerly painted for Shaw is to finish it by a further sitting. The latter part of the Evening I spent with Mr Hall the Sheriff, and learnt from him that Mr Palfrey took Offence at the little notice that he received from me on his visit to Washington last Spring—

19. V:30. My Sons John and Charles returned last Evening from Princeton, by the Stage through Lancaster to Boston. This morning Coll.Pickman, the son of my very old friend B. Pickman of Salem, came to me with an invitation from his father, that I would while remaining at Salem lodge at his house; which I accepted. I took my Son John with me, who for the sake of company consented to go. Leaving Boston at Nine we reached Salem at half past eleven—alighted at Mr Pickman’s, and I sent my Coachman with the Carriage and Horses to the Essex Coffee house— It happened there was this day the installation of Mr James Flint, as Minister of the Church, where the late Dr. Bentley had been settled; the ceremony had begun, and we immediately went with Mr Pickman and attended it— The Sermon which was excellent was by Mr Colman. The other performances, were by Mr Flint of Cohasset, brother of the Gentleman installed, Mr Bartlett of Beverley, my Classmate Dr. T. M. Harris, Mr Brazer, and Dr Prince, the Ministers of two other Churches in Salem— There were also performed two Anthems— The whole ceremony was of a character at once solemn and affecting, marked with characters of liberal sentiment, brotherly affection, and unassuming devotion— It was of little more than two hours duration, and on returning to Mr Pickman’s, I found waiting for me there, Mr James Perkins, and Coll. John T. Apthorp, who had followed me from Boston— They came as a Committee from a Meeting of Merchants there, with a Memorial to the President of the United States, which they requested me to forward to him— It was to request naval protection against piracies in the West-India seas, which have been of late greatly multiplied. I promised to forward the Memorial immediately— I dined with a party of about thirty Gentlemen, at Mr Silsbee’s, and among the company met there, my old Newbury-Port friend Dr Kilham, now living at Wenham. He is about 65. but bears about him the marks of age, beyond his years— After dinner, Mr Flint, and many of the persons who had officiated at his Installation joined the company at Mr Silsbee’s— Dr Holyoke came with them, who at the age of 93, is now the oldest surviving graduate of Harvard University. I spent the Evening at Mr Pickman’s, where there came several visitors— Among them Mr Peel, and Mr Peabody, who invited me to a club meeting at his house to morrow Evening.

20. VI: Morning visitors, Messrs. B. W. Crowninshield, and Silsbee and Judge Story. I wrote to D. Brent, and enclosed the Memorial to the President. Also to W. S. Shaw, from whom I received a Letter this morning, with information that my wife and my Son George reached Boston, returning from Princeton yesterday and immediately went out to my father’s: and Charles went with them. Mr Crowninshield very urgently invited me to dine with him before returning to Boston, and claimed a promise, which he said I had made him when I was here three years ago; but I have engaged to dine in Boston on Friday and excused myself to Crowninshield, by making him a new promise— I visited the Museum, which I had already seen when last here— A new arrangement of the Articles has since been made, and a curious collection of shells added— I then called at Mr Crowninshield’s, and afterwards took a ride with Mr Pickman to Wenham— We crossed the bridge where the contest between Coll. Leslie and his troops, and the people of Salem took place in the Spring of 1775 some weeks before the affair of Lexington, and Mr Pickman pointed out to me the spot where Governor Endicott had
had resided. My son John went with some of his Collegiate friends this afternoon to Nahant. I dined with a party of twenty Gentlemen at judge Story’s. We had after dinner a very animated conversation on the present condition of the University at Cambridge; in which a laxity of discipline, is a great and growing evil— I expressed my sentiments upon the subject with freedom. Mr Brazer who has lately been a tutor there undertook the defence of the Government, but without much success, being as he afterwards acknowledged to me, conscious of the weakness of his cause, and that there was room for complaint. From judge Story’s we went and passed the Evening at Mr Peabody’s. There was a supper. Most of the company was the same as at the judge’s; but Coll. Timothy Pickering was additional— He is 77 years of age, but in perfect health and as lively and cheerful in Spirits, as I ever knew him— He told however at supper, the Story of the discussion at Mr Jefferson’s table on the question whether the antient Romans had the art of making butter, or a word for it in their language— I had heard him tell it before, and Pickman says he tells it often, for the sake of exposing a mistake of Mr Jefferson’s, upon a point of classical antiquity— We came from Mr Peabody’s about 11. O’Clock. We have not seen Mrs Pickman this day, she having been confined to her chamber with a sick headache— They have six children living of whom only two grown up daughters, Martha and Elizabeth are with them. Their eldest daughter married to a young man named Rogers was with him, and their two infant children here yesterday, at dinner, and Rogers reminded me that he had been acquainted with me at St. Petersburg in 1810— Mrs Brazer the Clergyman’s wife dined here this day— I proposed to have called upon Mr and Mrs Felt, but John upon enquiry was told they were out of town. Giullé the Frenchman, ascended again this day in a Balloon at Boston and was seen from Nahant, and also from Salem— He came down again after a few minutes, near the end of one of the wharves.

21. VI:Judge Story called on me this morning after Breakfast, and we had an hour’s conversation together. He spoke with surprize of a rumour that the Commissioners of claims under the Spanish Treaty had decided not to receive any claims of Insurance companies— He said he could not credit the report, but that it had given great uneasiness here— I should have thought the report as incredible as judge Story, had I not heard Mr Crawford once express an opinion to the same effect. There are many consequences connected with this coincidence of opinions, upon some of which I will not yet indulge my own suspicions. There is danger of doing injustice by listening too much to suspicion. Several of the Gentlemen whom I met in company yesterday had mentioned to me this supposed decision of the Commissioners, with astonishment and alarm. I could give them no satisfaction concerning it. I returned with my Son, John this day to Boston, and on the way stopped to visit Commodore Hull, at the Navy Yard at Charleston; but did not find him at home. After alighting at Mrs Jenks’s I went to the Athenaeum, and there found large packets of despatches from the Department of State. I dined with the Lieutenant Governor Phillips, and a company of about 30 persons— After dinner, meeting Mr Webster he walked with me to Mrs Jenks’s and conversed with me on the subject of Lieutenant Stockton, and his recent captures— I mentioned to him that Judge Story had spoken to me of a recent decision by Sir William Scott against the right of capture in time of peace which seemed to settle the principle against Lieutenant Stockton; and told him of the President’s desire that the captured vessel which was brought in here, should be delivered up to the French Consul. He said he would send to Salem, and borrow the volume containing the report of the decision of Sir William Scott, and see me again upon the subject next week— I spent the Evening with Shaw, partly at J. H. Foster’s and the rest at judge Davis’s.

22. V:45. I wrote to D. Brent, and sent him a large packet of despatches for the Department of State— Commodore Bainbridge called on me this Morning, and conversed with me on the subject of Lieutenant Stockton’s captures— He says Stockton is an excellent Officer, and such is the universal
opinion; but Bainbridge thinks he ought not to have taken vessels under a foreign flag.— He also spoke to me of John Boyd with concern, and said he had been obliged to suspend him for some time from duty; but had restored him upon his promise of amendment. I told him I had obtained an order for him to go in the Franklin with Commodore Stewart to the Pacific Ocean; and he said it was the best thing that could be done for him. I called upon Mr Edward Everett, who spoke to me of the proposed review of Onis’s Memoir for the North-American Review— I told him it was impossible for me to write it now; but I would if I could possibly find time, after my return to Washington— He said Mr Farrar was to review my Report upon Weights and Measures, but that it would not be ready for the next number— I dined with a party of nine or ten gentlemen at Isaac P. Davis’s— It was the smallest, and by much the most pleasant dinner party at which I have been since I left Washington. J. Callender was of the Company, and revived many recollections of our old associate T. Crafts. In the Evening I came with W. S. Shaw and my Son John out to my father’s house at Quincy.

23. VI:15. Heard professor Ware, this morning from Ecclesiastes 3.10. “I have seen the travail, which God hath given to the sons of men, to be exercised in it.” and this afternoon from 2. Timothy 1.10. “But is now made manifest by the appearing of our Saviour Jesus Christ, who hath abolished death, and hath brought life and immortality to light through the gospel”— Mr Ware dined with us at my father’s; and in walking with him to the Meeting House after dinner, I spoke of the condition annexed to Charles’s Admission at the University and told him how much I had been affected by it— I also told him that I had myself examined Charles in various passages of Sallust, and although I had found him sometimes mistaking the sense of the author I had not seen that degree of deficiency, which I should have expected to warrant a condition upon his admission;—he told me that the usual practice was upon examinations, if the person failed at one passage to try him upon another; but this was not done to Charles— I examined him again this day in several passages of Sallust, and still found him construeing particular words incorrectly; that is assigning to the word a sense which belongs to it sometimes, but not in that sentence— To avoid this mistake requires a more thorough knowledge of the language than a freshman can possess. Yet I am satisfied that Charles is not well fitted in the Latin, and have no doubt he is at least equally deficient in the Greek. Had I known this sooner, I should have postponed offering him for another year— Degrand walked out this afternoon from Boston, but I did not see him. I went with George down to Mr. Quincy’s, and spent the Evening there.

24. VI: After being engaged early this morning in preparing a packet for the Department of State which I sent by W. S. Shaw, who returned in the Stage to Boston, I rode with my brother to the Mount Wollaston farm, and looked over the house, which has been repaired. The tenant now is a young man named Spear; to whom I have consented that it should be leased for three or five years. I have also given directions for the setting out of a young orchard there. While we were at the farm Mr. Eliphalet Loud of Weymouth after calling and not finding me at my father’s house, followed me down there, to enquire into the condition of his claim upon the Russian Government. It is precisely where it was twelve years ago— It was first presented by L. Harris, before my arrival at St. Petersburg in 1809. It was repeatedly renewed by me, and by all my successors at that Court, without ever obtaining an answer of any kind— A few Months since, I wrote a note to Mr Poletica the Russian Minister now here, requesting him to recommend this claim, and that of Mr I. Thorndike, under like circumstances, to the Consideration of his Government; which he has promised to do— All this I told Mr Loud, and all this could give him little satisfaction—
His claim is just, and all means short of Letters of reprizal have been resorted to, for obtaining satisfaction of it— This evening we all went to a tea party at Mr Quincy’s— But the weather was bad, and my brother’s children and my family were the only company there— The young people amused themselves with dancing.

25. VI:15. I came into Boston this morning with my Son George, who returned to Quincy this afternoon. I had a further Conversation with Mr. Daniel Webster, concerning Lieutenant Stockton and his captures— Webster has obtained from Judge Story the volume of Dodson’s Admiralty Reports containing the decision of Sir William Scott, and sent it to me, together with another similar decision in the English Court of King’s Bench of a yet later date. At the Athenaeum, I found two packets of despatches from the Department of State, one of which formed a folio volume from Governor Jackson at Pensacola; whose transactions there will occasion as much clamour, as his conduct in the Seminole War has done. I dined with a small company at Commodore Bainbridge’s, and spent part of the Evening with Shaw at Dr Welsh’s, and called at Mrs Storer’s, but she was not at home— Harriet Welsh said something to me, of going out with me to Quincy to-morrow evening; but said if she should, she would send me word in the course of the day.

26. VI: I was busied all the morning in reading a part of the despatches received yesterday from D. Brent; but it is the occupation of several days. I could not even reach General Jackson’s volume. At Noon I attended at the Boylston market Hall a Lecture upon Athens given by professor Everett. It was for the purpose of explaining and commenting upon the Panorama, of that City, now exhibited in the town. It contained much information upon the subject of Athens generally and of its history, delivered in plain language, without pretension to ornament; about an hour and a quarter long. To some of the opinions held forth in it, although in the literary fashion of the day, I am not yet prepared to subscribe—as for example, that the Doric is the most perfect and only rational order of architecture—The Tuscan being as he said too rude to deserve the name of an order, and the Ionic, Corinthian and Composite too fantastical, and tawdry— The rams horns, the acanthus leaves, and the pedestal, were all censured as unsuited to their purposes and places without considering at all their effect upon the eye— But magnificence is a legitimate object of public buildings as well as strength, and the ornamented orders are the most pleasing to the sight. He said also that the Drama, was the only Department of Literature in which the Greek writers were unrivalled. But he seemed only to mean that the modern Theatres of France and England were exhibitions, not precisely of the same kind as those of the Antient Greeks. Even in this sense, I think the observation should have been somewhat qualified. There were between three and four hundred persons present at this Lecture, more than half of whom were Ladies— I dined with a company of 25 at Mr Benjamin Joy’s, and there was conversation upon the literary merits of Lord Byron— I was surprized to hear Everett defend him, or at least palliate his vices— And still more so to hear him say that Steele’s papers in the Spectator were as loose in morals, as any thing of Byron’s— I gave my opinion of the licentiousness of Byron’s poetry, and its immorality; but said I was not disposed to judge him more severely than he had judged himself— John Welles came out with me from Joys, and told me, he was glad I had given my opinion so explicitly— Not having heard in the course of the day from Harriet Welsh, I came out this evening to my father’s house at Quincy, alone.

27. V:30. My Son George went into Boston, this morning, and brought out Harriet Welsh— W. S. Shaw came out with Stewart the painter, who brought with him the copy he had made of Shaw’s portrait of my father, and to whom my father gave a sitting of two or three hours— They returned this afternoon to Boston. Stewart paints this picture for a Mr Doggett, as one of the five Presidents of
the United States— He is to paint them all for him. There was an Evening party here, consisting of all the gentlefolks of Quincy, and they were more numerous, than I had ever seen in this place before. What I most remarked was the youthful part— The rising generation— There were I think in all more than one hundred persons—two thirds of them young people— They danced to the music of the piano, till near eleven, when the company broke up.

28. VI: This day the vacation at the University terminated, and the term commenced. I went with my Son Charles to Cambridge; and called with him first upon President Kirkland, who referred him for examination to Mr Channing— I asked if there would be any objection to my being present at the examination. The President answered no— I went therefore with Charles, and heard the examination. He passed through it, well with the exception of one word, vindicatum, which he construed vindicated, instead of punished; and from the mistake in the meaning of that word, he missed that of the whole Sentence. Mr Channing however gave him a certificate; upon which President Kirkland granted his admittatur. He then went to the Steward’s and entered his own name and John’s, with permission to come next Monday for regular attendance to the term. I asked President Kirkland, to shew me the graduated lists which shew the standing of the Students at the several recitations which he did. I found George’s standing in his class was N. 30. and John in his N. 45. I wished to have some conversation with Dr Kirkland upon this subject, but he was this day so much engaged, with the examinations that I postponed speaking to him of it. I called at Dr Waterhouse’s, and returned him the Letters from Dr. Gordon and Dr Jebb, which he had lent me. He spoke to me again about an appointment of Collector at Marblehead, or somewhere for his Son; but those appointments are not within my province— I then came in to Boston, with Charles and he returned this afternoon to Quincy. I called at George Blake’s Office, concerning the affair of Lieutenant Stockton— I had read the two cases reported in Dodson’s, and in Barnwall and Alderson’s Reports, and expressed to Blake, my doubts whether upon the principle of those decisions, there was a right in time of peace in the naval officers of one Nation, even to board the merchant vessels of another— He also spoke to me of several persons lately brought in here upon a charge of piracy. Judge Davis had mentioned them to me before and had sent me the only commission that they had; which was from Luis Aury, professing himself to be commissioned by the Governments of Buenos Ayres and Chili— I told Blake, that was itself piracy by the privateering ordinances both of Buenos-Ayres and Chili, and referred him to the Buenos Ayrean, Ordinance in the Appendix to theVolume of Wheaton’s Reports— I called at Welles and Lilly’s Bookstore, and bespoke a considerable collection of books, with orders to send them to the Department of State, at Washington— Dined at Mr Thorndike’s with a company of near thirty Gentlemen— As we were retiring after dinner General Sumner mentioned a Methodist preacher named Maffitt much celebrated for eloquence, and who is said to be performing marvelous conversions. He was to preach this Evening, and I went with Sumner, intending to hear him; but the crowd was so great, that we could not get even into the house— I then went and passed the Evening at the Athenaeum— Mr Harris the Marshal of the District and Sheriff Hall were there— I agreed to Breakfast with Hall to-morrow, and then go with him to visit Governor Brooks at Medford.

29. V:15. Breakfasted, with Sheriff Hall, and then went with him in a Chaise to Medford, where we saw the Governor. He lent me two pamphlets which he had received from Coll. Aspinwall, at London, relating to the Greek Insurrection, which is now shaking Europe and Asia— On returning to Boston I met Mr Wait the printer, and went with him to see the new printing press invented by Tredwell; it is a great improvement upon that which he had invented and which I saw two years ago. Tredwell has since been to England and by his present invention, the power of one horse
keeps four presses in motion at the same time. Only one of the presses has yet been set up; and his machinery operated successfully with that— My Son George was in town from Quincy; and told me of the loss of a sum of money, 35 dollars, which his mother gave him, for J. Q. A. Boyd, which he gave to T. Bracket, and T. Bracket, to a midshipman of the Columbus, whose very name he did not know. The natural consequence has followed— The money has been lost, and even the Officer to whom it was entrusted, is not to be found. The loss of the money, I thought nothing of, but the heedlessness and want of consideration in my Son afflicted me, and I spoke harshly to him. His health is not good, and what I said affected him so much that I repented of my own unkindness— I told him to get a certificate from T. Bracket that he had delivered the note containing the money, to an Officer of the Columbus, and to write a Letter to Commodore Bainbridge requesting him to have enquiry made for the Officer and the money. We dined at Mr Little’s, with General Boyd, and a company of thirty persons— Little lives at the North end, in the house where Governor Hutchinson resided, before the revolution— The company were miscellaneous, and among them were the two Generals Dearborn, father and Son; the two Austin’s, and D. De Forrest, the quondam Consul from Buenos Ayres, and whom I had lately seen at New Haven— I asked G. Blake whether De Forrest had not come here on account of the pirates lately brought in under the Buenos-Ayrean flag— He did not know— General Dearborn the elder, told me that he wished to have some conversation with me; and I promised to call upon him at his house next Tuesday at noon. Degrand told me he would come out to see me at Quincy tomorrow. I came out in the Evening with George, to my father’s and found Shaw, who had come out with Quincy, here.

30. V:15. I had a sleepless Night— Cares for the welfare and future prospects of my children; mortification at the discovery how much they have wasted of their time at Cambridge, and concern for the health of George, agitated my mind so much that through the Night I could not close my eyes— I had hoped that at least one of my Sons would have been ambitious to excel— I find them all three, coming to manhood, with indolent minds— Flinching from study whenever they can, and if not content to hold the 30th. and forty-fifth rank in their class, incapable of the exertion necessary for raising them higher. It is bitter disappointment. The blast of mediocrity, is the lightest of the evils, which such characters portend— My reflections on my pillow were occupied in the enquiry what was the path of my own duty upon this state of things; and I concluded, after expressing my sentiments to John and Charles, to direct them to pass their next winter vacation, here at Quincy, with my father. For which I this day asked his permission and obtained his ready consent— I shall take George with me to Washington, and have him under my own eye. He is not without ambition, and has lost his time more by a social disposition, than actual neglect— Upon the others I can operate only indirectly— I heard a young man named Walter this morning from Exodus 3.14. “And God said unto Moses, I AM THAT I AM”— His afternoon text was from 2. Corinthians 4.18. “While we look not at the things which are seen, but at the things which are not seen; for the things which are seen are temporal, but the things which are not seen are eternal.” These Sermons were the first performances of this Gentleman in the pulpit, and bore marks of youth and immature judgment, not without a mixture of high and vivid eloquence— The composition was too poetical and ambitious of ornament for the taste of his hearers— He has published a volume of poetry also of a juvenile and imitative character— He dined with us at my fathers— There was company too here as usually, on Sunday Evening’s— Mr and Mrs Quincy, Mrs Black and her niece, Captain Beale, and Mr Marston, the latter of whom again applied to me for an appointment upon very urgent considerations— Degrand likewise came out from Boston and gave me the papers relative to the claim of Joseph N. Howe— And I agreed to meet him with a Committee of Memorialists to the President on the subject of a Bankrupt act on Tuesday at half past one O’Clock in Boston.
Day— This Month has been passed on the wing; never three days together at the same place. My distribution of time therefore has been irregular and casual.
